overview_metadata.overview_subtitle: Solutions to Quadratic Equations in Vertex Form
overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students use the Properties of Equality and square roots to solve quadratic equations of the form <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>c</mi><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>c</mi><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mi>d</mi></math> and determine how the translations affect the solutions. Students learn that a quadratic function can have one unique real zero, two real zeros, or no real zeros, and how the number of real zeros relates to the graph of the function.

overview_item_data_items: I can solve quadratic equations in vertex form by taking square roots and explain the meaning of the solutions.
I can solve quadratic equations in different forms and use structure to choose an appropriate solving method.
I can use graphs to interpret the solutions of a quadratic equation and explain how they relate to the equation.
I can explain how the number of solutions to a quadratic equation relates to the graph of the function.

The solutions to a quadratic equation of the form <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>c</mi><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></math> are <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>±</mo><msqrt><mi>y</mi></msqrt></math>.

The solutions to a quadratic equation of the form <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>c</mi><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>d</mi></math> are <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>±</mo><msqrt><mfrac><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>d</mi></mrow><mi>a</mi></mfrac></msqrt></math>.

The solutions to a quadratic equation of the form <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>c</mi><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mi>d</mi></math> are <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>±</mo><msqrt><mfrac><mi>d</mi><mi>a</mi></mfrac></msqrt></math>.
A quadratic equation has one unique, two, or no real roots. The number of real roots corresponds to the number of x-intercepts.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students describe transformations of quadratic functions by connecting graphical representations to algebraic equations.
Students analyze solutions from graphical representations to the solutions determined algebraically.
Students generalize their understandings about the solutions to quadratic equations in vertex form

Students solve quadratic equations of the form <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>c</mi><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, where a â‰  1.
Students write the general solutions to a quadratic equation expressed in vertex form.

overview_item_data_items: If facilitating this lesson without student devices, no additional materials are needed.
To avoid printing additional materials not included in MATHbook (like Activate activities and Session Quick Checks) project them using the Present button above.
